title: Chest Pain Treatment
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: For possible heart attack symptoms and treatment, see Heart Attack Treatment .

content_blocks.text: For possible heart attack symptoms and treatment, see Heart Attack Treatment .

sections.heading: For Angina
content: If the person gets angina and has been prescribed nitroglycerin:
If the person has been diagnosed with chronic stable angina:
If the person goes to the hospital:
bullets: Dissolve 1 nitroglycerin tablet under the tongue (or use nitroglycerin spray under the tongue ).
Wait 5 minutes.
If the person still has angina, call 911.
Dissolve 1 nitroglycerin tablet under the tongue (or use nitroglycerin spray under the tongue).
Repeat every 5 minutes until the person has taken 3 tablets in 15 minutes.
If the person still has angina after 3 doses, call 911

An emergency department doctor will examine the person and run tests to see if the chest pain stems from a heart attack or another cause. Tests may include an electrocardiogram (ECG), chest X-ray, and blood tests.
Inform the person’s doctor about the chest pain and ER visit.

content_blocks.text: If the person gets angina and has been prescribed nitroglycerin:
associated_bullets: Dissolve 1 nitroglycerin tablet under the tongue (or use nitroglycerin spray under the tongue ).
If the person still has angina, call 911.

content_blocks.text: If the person has been diagnosed with chronic stable angina:
associated_bullets: Dissolve 1 nitroglycerin tablet under the tongue (or use nitroglycerin spray under the tongue).
Repeat every 5 minutes until the person has taken 3 tablets in 15 minutes.
If the person still has angina after 3 doses, call 911

content_blocks.text: If the person goes to the hospital:
associated_bullets: An emergency department doctor will examine the person and run tests to see if the chest pain stems from a heart attack or another cause. Tests may include an electrocardiogram (ECG), chest X-ray, and blood tests.
Inform the person’s doctor about the chest pain and ER visit.

sections.heading: For GERD (Acid Reflux)
content: Call 911 if: The person has possible heart attack symptoms, such as shortness of breath, flushed sweating , nausea or vomiting , or arm or jaw pain . Heart attacks can be mistaken for GERD.
bullets: If the person goes to the hospital, an emergency department doctor will examine the person and run tests to see if the chest pain stems from a heart attack or another cause. Tests may include an electrocardiogram (ECG), chest X-ray, and blood tests.
Inform the person’s doctor about the chest pain and ER visit.

Inform the person’s doctor about the chest pain and ER visit.

sources: Cleveland Clinic: “Call 911 -- Before It’s Too Late,” “Symptoms of Coronary Artery Disease.”
meta_description: WebMD walks you through first aid treatment of chest pain, or angina.
